description.short: Identifies failure to recognize and manage interdependencies between security domains, creating cascading vulnerabilities when coupled systems interact unexpectedly
description.context: System coupling failures represent psychological inability to recognize and manage interdependencies between seemingly separate security domains. This vulnerability emerges from cognitive compartmentalization - the mental tendency to treat interconnected systems as isolated entities - serving a defensive function by reducing cognitive load but creating dangerous blind spots where vulnerabilities cascade through coupled systems.
description.impact: Organizations with unmanaged coupling suffer cascading failures: NotPetya 2017 (legitimate system coupling became attack vector spreading globally), Target 2013 (HVAC vendor coupling to payment systems), SolarWinds 2020 (trusted software update coupling amplified supply chain attack), Colonial Pipeline 2021 (IT/OT coupling enabled ransomware to disrupt physical infrastructure). Common patterns include lateral movement through unexpected pathways, cascade failures propagating across domains, and insider threats amplified through excessive coupling.
description.psychological_basis: Cognitive Compartmentalization - mental tendency to treat interconnected systems as isolated. Systems Theory (Perrow, 1984) - tightly coupled systems create unavoidable failure modes. Cognitive Load Theory (Miller, 1956) - limited working memory prevents comprehensive mental modeling of complex interconnections. Bion's Basic Assumptions (1961) - psychological defenses obscure system interdependencies. Neuroscience (Buckner et al., 2008) - brain's default mode toward simplified linear thinking.

scoring.formula: Final_Score = (w1 × Quick_Assessment + w2 × Conversation_Depth + w3 × Red_Flags) × Coupling_Density_Multiplier

green.label: Low Vulnerability - Managed Coupling
green.description: Formal process for documenting system connections before implementation. Regular (quarterly or more) review of system dependencies. Standard incident response includes checking connected systems. Emergency changes have mandatory connection impact checks. Cross-team coordination required and documented. Network segmentation aligned with security boundaries.

yellow.label: Moderate Vulnerability - Partial Awareness
yellow.description: Some documentation of system connections but incomplete or outdated. Occasional unexpected impacts from system changes (1-2 per quarter). Incident response sometimes includes connection checks. Emergency changes have informal connection considerations. Cross-team coordination happens but not consistently documented. Some network segmentation but enforcement gaps.

red.label: High Vulnerability - Coupling Blindness
red.description: Little to no documentation of system connections. Frequent unexpected impacts from system changes (monthly or more). Incident response focuses only on directly affected systems. Emergency changes proceed without connection impact analysis. Teams work in isolation with minimal coordination. Flat network topology with excessive coupling.

mathematical_model.primary: SCF(t) = Σ(i=1 to n) Σ(j>i) C(i,j)·(1 - A(i,j))·I(i,j)

system_coupling_failure_index.formula: SCF(t) = Σ(i=1 to n) Σ(j>i) C(i,j)·(1 - A(i,j))·I(i,j)
system_coupling_failure_index.description: Pairwise coupling risk across all system combinations weighted by awareness gaps

variables.C(i,j): coupling strength between systems i and j (0-1)
variables.n: number of distinct systems or domains

coupling_density_metric.description: Network density of system connections normalized by complexity

thresholds.high_coupling: CD ≥ 0.6 indicates excessive coupling requiring attention

cascade_failure_probability.description: Probability that initial vulnerability cascades through coupled systems

variables.p_i: probability of vulnerability in system i
variables.c_i: coupling strength of system i to other systems

interpretation.D < 0.3: Managed coupling with good awareness and documentation
interpretation.0.3 ≤ D < 0.6: Partial coupling awareness with some blind spots
interpretation.D ≥ 0.6: Critical coupling failures - systemic blind spots and cascade risks

detection_formula.baseline_establishment: 90-day rolling window with architecture change adjustment

technical.collection_method: Automated network discovery and traffic analysis
Change record analysis and outcome tracking
Incident classification and impact scope analysis

human.collection_method: Structured architecture assessments with coupling analysis

sections.title: Quick Assessment - System Coupling Failures
sections.instructions: Answer the following questions based on how your organization manages connections and interdependencies between systems. Focus on actual practices for understanding and controlling system coupling.

items.prompt: Tell us about a specific recent system implementation and what documentation was created about its connections.

options.label: Comprehensive connection documentation required before implementation with regular updates
options.follow_up: Show us an example of your integration documentation.

options.label: Basic connection documentation created but not always comprehensive or kept current
options.follow_up: What prevents documentation from staying current?

options.label: Minimal documentation of connections; relies on technical team knowledge
options.follow_up: How do you track all system connections without documentation?

options.label: No systematic documentation of system connections; discovered through troubleshooting
options.follow_up: How do you assess impact of changes without connection documentation?

red_flags: System connections discovered only during incidents
No architecture diagrams showing system relationships
Integration documentation more than 6 months outdated
items.title: When you implement a new system or make significant changes to existing ones, what process do you follow to document how it connects to other systems?

items.prompt: Give us a recent example where a change in one system affected another system that wasn't expected to be impacted.

options.label: Rare unexpected impacts (<1 per quarter); coupling well understood and managed
options.follow_up: How do you achieve such predictable change outcomes?

options.label: Occasional unexpected impacts (1-2 per quarter); usually identified and resolved quickly
options.follow_up: What causes the unexpected impacts you do experience?

options.label: Frequent unexpected impacts (monthly or more); coupling complexity makes prediction difficult
options.follow_up: How does this affect your willingness to make necessary changes?

options.label: Unexpected impacts are routine; changes regularly cause cascade failures across systems
options.follow_up: What's your strategy for managing these cascade failures?

red_flags: Changes regularly rolled back due to unexpected system impacts
Extended change windows due to unpredictable coupling effects
Pattern of cascade failures from single system changes
items.title: How often do system changes cause unexpected problems in other, seemingly unrelated systems?

items.prompt: Describe your most recent security incident and which systems you checked for potential impact.

options.label: Systematic assessment of all connected systems using documented dependency maps
options.follow_up: Walk us through your connection checking procedure.

options.label: Check obviously connected systems; may miss indirect coupling relationships
options.follow_up: How do you identify which systems to check?

options.label: Focus on directly affected systems; discover connected impacts reactively as they surface
options.follow_up: How often do you discover additional affected systems after initial response?

options.label: Incident response treats systems as isolated; rarely checks for connected impacts
options.follow_up: How do you prevent incidents from spreading to connected systems?

red_flags: Incidents spread to systems not included in initial response
No dependency maps available for incident response
Extended containment times due to cascade discovery
items.title: When you experience a security incident, what's your standard procedure for checking if other systems might be affected?

items.prompt: Tell us about a recent vendor implementation and how you assessed its connections to your existing systems.

options.label: Comprehensive vendor connection mapping with documented data flows and security controls
options.follow_up: Show us an example of your vendor connection documentation.

options.label: Basic understanding of vendor connections but not always comprehensively documented
options.follow_up: What prevents comprehensive vendor connection documentation?

options.label: Limited visibility into vendor connections; understand primary integration only
options.follow_up: How do you assess security risks without understanding all vendor connections?

options.label: Vendor connections not systematically tracked; discovered through troubleshooting or incidents
options.follow_up: How do you prevent vendor security issues from affecting internal systems?

red_flags: Vendor security incidents affecting unexpected internal systems
No visibility into vendor data flows and system access
Vendor integrations approved without connection security assessment
items.title: What process do you use to understand and manage how third-party systems connect to your internal systems?

items.prompt: Show us your most recent system dependency documentation and when it was last updated.

options.label: Continuous automated dependency tracking with quarterly manual validation and updates
options.follow_up: How does your automated dependency tracking work?

options.label: Semi-annual or annual dependency reviews with updates as major changes occur
options.follow_up: What triggers dependency documentation updates?

options.label: Dependency documentation updated reactively when issues reveal gaps or errors
options.follow_up: How do you know when dependency documentation is inaccurate?

options.label: No systematic dependency review; documentation becomes outdated quickly
options.follow_up: How do you make decisions without current dependency information?

red_flags: Dependency documentation more than 12 months old
Significant gaps between documented and actual dependencies
Decisions based on outdated dependency assumptions
items.title: How frequently do you review and update documentation about which systems depend on each other?

items.prompt: Give us an example of your last emergency change and what checks were performed.

options.label: Mandatory connection impact checklist even during emergencies; documented review required
options.follow_up: Walk us through your emergency connection check procedure.

options.label: Informal connection consideration during emergencies; relies on team knowledge
options.follow_up: How reliable are informal checks under time pressure?

options.label: Emergency changes proceed with minimal connection assessment; fix issues reactively
options.follow_up: How often do emergency changes cause connection problems?

options.label: Emergency procedures bypass connection assessment; focus solely on immediate issue
options.follow_up: What's your process for recovering from connection breaks caused by emergency changes?

red_flags: Emergency changes routinely breaking system connections
No rapid connection assessment procedures for emergencies
Extended outages from emergency change cascade failures
items.title: When you need to make emergency changes to critical systems, what steps ensure you don't break connections to other systems?

items.prompt: Describe a recent example where multiple teams had to coordinate on a system change.

options.label: Formal cross-team coordination required and documented for all changes affecting multiple domains
options.follow_up: How does your cross-team coordination process work?

options.label: Informal coordination happens but not always documented or comprehensive
options.follow_up: What causes coordination gaps in your process?

options.label: Teams coordinate reactively when conflicts arise; minimal proactive coordination
options.follow_up: How often do coordination failures cause problems?

options.label: Teams work in isolation; coordination breakdowns are common
options.follow_up: How do you resolve conflicts when teams make incompatible changes?

red_flags: Frequent conflicts from uncoordinated team changes
No cross-team change approval requirements
Team silos preventing visibility into interdependent changes
items.title: How do different IT teams (network, security, applications, etc.) coordinate when making changes that might affect other teams' systems?

sections.title: Client Conversation Guide - System Coupling Failures

conversation_framework.introduction: I'd like to understand how your organization manages the connections and interdependencies between different systems. Let's talk about how systems integrate and how you track those relationships.
principles: Focus on actual system coupling vs. documented architecture
Explore awareness of direct and indirect dependencies
Identify coordination mechanisms for coupled systems
Listen for surprise at coupling-related failures
Note gaps between assumed and actual system relationships

conversation_sections.opening: Let's start by discussing how you track and document connections between your different systems. Walk me through how you understand your system architecture.

core_questions.question: How do you document and track how your systems connect to each other?
core_questions.purpose: Assess coupling awareness and documentation practices
listen_for: Gaps between documented and actual connections
probes: When was your system architecture documentation last updated?
How do you discover new system connections?
Can you show me an example of your integration documentation?

core_questions.question: Have you ever been surprised by how a change in one system affected other systems?
core_questions.purpose: Identify coupling blindness and cascade failure patterns
probes: Give me a specific example of an unexpected connection.
What did you learn from that experience?
How often do you encounter these surprises?

red_flags: Outdated or incomplete system architecture documentation
Frequent surprise at system interaction failures
System connections discovered only during incidents
No automated dependency tracking or discovery

conversation_sections.opening: Now let's talk about how you manage changes to systems and assess their potential impacts. Walk me through a recent significant system change.

core_questions.question: What's your process for assessing how a change to one system might affect other systems?
core_questions.purpose: Evaluate change impact analysis depth and coupling consideration
listen_for: Tools and processes for dependency checking
probes: How do you identify all potentially affected systems?
What tools do you use for impact analysis?
How often does your impact analysis miss connections?

core_questions.question: How often do changes cause problems in systems you didn't expect to be affected?
core_questions.purpose: Quantify coupling failure frequency and organizational learning
listen_for: Root causes of impact prediction failures
probes: What percentage of changes have unexpected impacts?
What causes you to miss these connections?
Have you improved your impact analysis based on these experiences?

red_flags: Changes routinely causing unexpected system impacts
No formal change impact analysis process
Extended change windows due to unpredictable coupling
Pattern of cascade failures from single changes

conversation_sections.opening: When you have a security incident, let's discuss how you determine what systems are affected. Walk me through your last significant incident.

core_questions.question: What's your procedure for checking which systems might be affected by a security incident?
core_questions.purpose: Assess incident scope assessment and coupling awareness
listen_for: Use of dependency maps in incident response
probes: Do you have dependency maps available during incidents?
How do you identify indirectly connected systems?
How often do you discover additional affected systems later?

core_questions.question: Has an incident ever spread to systems you didn't initially realize were connected?
listen_for: Time to discover full incident scope
probes: Give me a specific example.
How long did it take to discover the full scope?
What would have helped you identify the connections sooner?

red_flags: Incidents spreading beyond initially assessed scope
No systematic procedure for checking connected systems
Extended containment times due to cascade discovery
Repeated patterns of coupling-based incident propagation

conversation_sections.opening: Let's discuss how third-party systems connect to your internal infrastructure and how you manage those relationships.

core_questions.question: How do you assess and document how vendor systems connect to your internal systems?
core_questions.purpose: Evaluate third-party coupling management and visibility
probes: Show me an example of vendor connection documentation.
How do you assess security risks of vendor connections?
Do you know all the systems a vendor can access?

core_questions.question: Have you experienced security issues where vendor access affected more internal systems than expected?
core_questions.purpose: Identify vendor coupling blind spots and risks
listen_for: Extent of vendor access and coupling
Lessons learned from vendor coupling issues
probes: What systems did the vendor access affect?
How did you discover the full extent of vendor connections?
What changes did you make after that incident?

red_flags: Vendor access to unexpected internal systems
No comprehensive vendor connection documentation
Vendor security incidents with broad internal impact
Vendor integrations approved without coupling assessment

synthesis.instructions: After completing the conversation, synthesize findings to assess overall system coupling failure vulnerability.
synthesis_questions: How comprehensive is system coupling documentation and how current is it?
How frequently do coupling surprises occur (change impacts, incident scope)?
What processes exist for coupling assessment and management?
How effective is cross-team coordination on coupled systems?
What evidence exists of learning from coupling failures?

scoring_guidance.green: Comprehensive coupling documentation kept current, rare unexpected impacts, systematic impact and scope assessment, formal cross-team coordination, effective vendor coupling management, learning from coupling events
scoring_guidance.yellow: Basic coupling documentation with some gaps, occasional unexpected impacts, informal assessment processes, ad-hoc coordination, partial vendor coupling visibility, limited systematic learning
scoring_guidance.red: Poor or missing coupling documentation, frequent unexpected impacts, no systematic assessment, siloed teams, vendor coupling blind spots, repeated coupling failures without learning

temporal_factors.early_warning_threshold: Increasing frequency of unexpected change impacts or incident cascade failures

cross_validation.relationship: Emergence unpredictability should correlate with coupling failure patterns
cross_validation.action_if_divergent: Investigate whether coupling is recognized but emergence patterns missed

cross_validation.relationship: Cascade failures should exploit unmanaged coupling relationships
cross_validation.action_if_divergent: Assess whether cascades occur through other mechanisms

solutions.title: Automated Network Dependency Mapping and Visualization Platform
solutions.description: Deploy automated network discovery tools that continuously map system connections and dependencies. Provides real-time visibility into system coupling with automated alerts for new or changed relationships.
implementation_steps: Deploy network discovery platform with automated connection mapping
Implement application dependency mapping for software-level coupling
Create visual dependency graphs showing system relationships
Configure automated alerts for new or modified system connections
Establish weekly automated scans with monthly manual validation
Integrate dependency maps with change management and incident response
Create coupling risk scoring based on dependency complexity
Develop executive dashboards showing coupling density and risks
Train teams on dependency map interpretation and usage
metrics: 100% of system connections automatically discovered and mapped
Weekly dependency map updates with <5% variance from actual
New connection discovery within 24 hours of creation
Dependency map integration with 90% of change and incident processes
solutions.evidence_basis: Network science research on dependency visualization improving failure prevention

solutions.title: Cross-System Change Impact Approval Process
solutions.description: Establish mandatory change review process requiring impact analysis for any system modifications, including checklist of potentially connected systems with approval from owners of connected systems.
implementation_steps: Create change request template requiring connection impact analysis
Develop automated system connection lookup during change request
Implement approval workflow requiring connected system owner signoff
Establish connection impact assessment checklist by system type
Configure automated notifications to potentially affected system owners
Create escalation process for connection impact disputes
Implement post-change validation of connection health
Track and analyze unexpected connection impacts for process improvement
Develop metrics showing change impact prediction accuracy
metrics: 100% of changes include documented connection impact analysis
Unexpected change impacts reduced >80% within 6 months
Connected system owner approval for >95% of multi-system changes
solutions.cost_estimate: Medium ($30K-$75K for process and workflow automation)
solutions.evidence_basis: Change management research on impact analysis reducing unintended consequences

solutions.title: Incident Response Connection Checking Protocol
solutions.description: Develop incident response playbook that includes mandatory steps for checking connected systems, with specific checklists for common system types and dependency map integration.
implementation_steps: Create incident response procedure requiring connected system assessment
Develop system-type-specific connection checking checklists
Integrate dependency maps into incident response tools and procedures
Train incident response team on connection analysis techniques
Implement automated connection query tools for rapid lookup
Establish connection impact assessment timelines (<30 min initial, <2 hr comprehensive)
Create incident scope documentation requirements including connections
Develop post-incident connection review to validate assessment completeness
Track incidents where connection checking prevented cascade failures
metrics: 100% of incidents include documented connection assessment
Mean time to connection assessment <30 minutes
Incident cascade beyond initial scope reduced >70%
Connection-based containment improvements in >60% of incidents
solutions.cost_estimate: Low to Medium ($15K-$40K for playbooks and training)
solutions.evidence_basis: Incident response research on scope assessment improving containment

solutions.title: Quarterly System Relationship and Dependency Reviews
solutions.description: Schedule regular cross-team meetings to review and update system dependency documentation, with representatives from all IT teams creating collaborative dependency validation.
implementation_steps: Establish quarterly system relationship review meeting schedule
Create standardized review agenda focusing on connection accuracy and changes
Require representation from network, security, application, and infrastructure teams
Develop dependency validation checklist for systematic review
Implement collaborative dependency map updating during reviews
Document new connections, changed relationships, and deprecated integrations
Create action items for connection security improvements
Track dependency documentation accuracy improvements over time
Share review outcomes with leadership and stakeholders
metrics: Cross-team participation rate >90% of required representatives
Dependency documentation accuracy improvement >50% in first year
Connection security improvements >30 per year from review findings
solutions.cost_estimate: Low ($5K-$15K annually for facilitation and coordination)
solutions.evidence_basis: Organizational learning research on collaborative reviews improving shared mental models

solutions.title: Vendor Integration Security Assessment and Mapping
solutions.description: Develop vendor onboarding checklist that requires detailed analysis of how third-party systems will connect to internal infrastructure with comprehensive connection security review.
implementation_steps: Create vendor security assessment template including connection mapping requirements
Develop vendor connection documentation standards and examples
Implement vendor data flow diagram requirements for all integrations
Establish vendor connection security review process before approval
Create vendor access and connection monitoring requirements
Implement quarterly vendor connection reviews for existing vendors
Develop vendor connection risk scoring methodology
Require vendor incident notification and connection impact assessment
Track vendor-related incidents and connection security improvements
metrics: 100% of new vendors with documented connection analysis before approval
Vendor connection security assessments for >90% of existing vendors within 6 months
Vendor-related security incidents affecting unexpected systems reduced >75%
Vendor connection monitoring implemented for >95% of critical integrations
solutions.cost_estimate: Medium ($25K-$60K for process and assessment tools)
solutions.evidence_basis: Supply chain security research on vendor connection visibility reducing third-party risks

solutions.title: Emergency Change Rapid Connection Assessment Procedure
solutions.description: Create mandatory rapid assessment tool for emergency changes that lists common system connections and requires verification before proceeding, with 15-minute emergency connection check capability.
implementation_steps: Develop rapid connection check procedure executable in <15 minutes
Create system-specific emergency connection checklists
Implement quick-reference connection guide for common systems
Train on-call staff on emergency connection assessment procedures
Establish emergency approval workflow including connection verification
Create automated connection lookup tools for emergency use
Implement emergency change connection validation documentation
Develop rollback procedures for connection-breaking emergency changes
Track emergency changes and connection impact outcomes
metrics: 100% of emergency changes include documented connection check
Emergency connection assessment completed within 15 minutes
Emergency changes causing connection failures reduced >80%
Emergency change rollback rate reduced >60% through connection checking
solutions.cost_estimate: Low ($8K-$20K for procedures and quick-reference tools)
solutions.evidence_basis: Emergency response research on rapid assessment checklists preventing errors under pressure

risk_scenarios.title: APT Lateral Movement Through Undocumented Coupling
risk_scenarios.description: Advanced Persistent Threat attackers compromise low-security systems and use undocumented connections to access critical business systems through lateral movement pathways that defenders don't realize exist.

attack_pattern.reconnaissance: Mapping organization's system coupling through external scanning and OSINT
attack_pattern.timing: Initial compromise of weakly defended systems with extensive undocumented coupling
attack_pattern.execution: Multi-hop lateral movement through unexpected coupling pathways
attack_pattern.exploitation: Critical system compromise and data exfiltration through coupling chains

real_world_examples: Target 2013: HVAC vendor coupling to payment systems enabled payment card data theft
APT campaigns using IT support system coupling to access production environments
indicators: Lateral movement between systems without obvious connections
Data exfiltration pathways through coupled systems
Authentication anomalies in coupled system relationships

mitigation_mapping.network_dependency_mapping: Provides visibility into lateral movement pathways
mitigation_mapping.incident_connection_protocol: Enables systematic checking of coupled systems during incidents

risk_scenarios.title: Supply Chain Attack Amplification Through Trust Coupling
risk_scenarios.description: Software update from trusted vendor contains malicious code that spreads through connected systems beyond originally targeted application because organization doesn't know which systems share connections with vendor software.

attack_pattern.reconnaissance: Understanding of vendor software coupling and trust relationships
attack_pattern.timing: Malicious code injection into trusted vendor update
attack_pattern.execution: Propagation through vendor software connections to internal systems
attack_pattern.exploitation: Complete network compromise through cascading trust relationships

real_world_examples: SolarWinds 2020: Trusted software update coupling enabled widespread compromise across 18,000+ organizations
NotPetya 2017: Ukrainian tax software coupling enabled global ransomware spread
indicators: Vendor software update affecting unexpected internal systems
Cascading failures following vendor software changes
Unusual data flows from vendor-connected systems
Trust relationship exploitation across system boundaries

mitigation_mapping.vendor_integration_assessment: Documents and controls vendor system coupling
mitigation_mapping.cross_system_change_approval: Requires assessment of vendor update impacts

risk_scenarios.title: Cascading System Failures From Unrecognized Dependencies
risk_scenarios.description: Routine maintenance change to one system causes unexpected failures in connected systems creating security window that attackers exploit while defenders struggle with cascade containment.

attack_pattern.reconnaissance: Monitoring for organizational change windows and coupling complexity
attack_pattern.timing: Attack launched during cascade failure window when security degraded
attack_pattern.execution: Exploitation of security controls disabled during cascade response
attack_pattern.exploitation: Data exfiltration or persistent access during extended recovery period

real_world_examples: Major cloud provider outages where cascading failures created prolonged security control degradation
Database maintenance causing authentication system failures enabling unauthorized access
indicators: Cascade failures propagating across supposedly isolated systems
Extended recovery times due to coupling complexity
Security controls disabled during cascade troubleshooting
Attack activities coinciding with cascade failure periods

risk_scenarios.title: Cloud-to-Premises Bridge Attack via Hidden Coupling
risk_scenarios.description: Attackers compromise cloud service that has hidden connections to on-premises systems through single sign-on, shared databases, or backup systems, treating cloud and on-premises as separate security domains while missing coupling-based attack bridges.

attack_pattern.reconnaissance: Identifying cloud-to-premises coupling points and trust relationships
attack_pattern.timing: Cloud service compromise followed by pivot through coupling to on-premises
attack_pattern.execution: Exploitation of shared identity, data, or backup coupling for lateral movement
attack_pattern.exploitation: Complete infrastructure compromise across cloud and on-premises through coupling bridges

real_world_examples: Cloud identity provider compromises enabling on-premises Active Directory access
Cloud backup service coupling enabling on-premises data access and exfiltration
indicators: Cloud authentication used for on-premises access
Data synchronization anomalies between cloud and on-premises
Backup system access from cloud credentials
